intro: Oligochaetochilus ovatus, commonly known as the ovate-stemmed moss, is a member of the family Dicranaceae. It is a small, terrestrial moss that typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forest floors or rocky crevices. The plant has slender, wiry stems that are often covered in minute, tubular leaves. Its reproductive structures, known as capsules, are borne on short, erect stems and release spores when mature. Oligochaetochilus ovatus plays a role in soil stabilization and provides habitat for microorganisms in its native ecosystems.
